sanskrit_verse:
अभ्रिं कार्ष्णायसीं दद्यात्सर्पं हत्वा द्विजोत्तमः ।
पलालभारकं षण्ढे सैसकं चैकमाषकम् ॥ ११.१३३॥
transliteration:
abhriṃ kārṣṇāyasīṃ dadyāt sarpaṃ hatvā dvijottamaḥ |
palālabhārakaṃ ṣaṇḍhe saisakaṃ caikamāṣakam || 11.133||
sph_interpretive_translation: The twice-born who has killed a serpent shall give iron, black antimony, a lump of clay, and one masha of sesamum seeds.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority resides in the act of purification through restitution
Causation arises from conscious intent manifesting in action
Capacity-based responsibility is determined by ritual status and spiritual maturity
Restoration logic requires material return aligned with energetic disruption
Consciousness alignment occurs via corrective offering and completion
executable_legal_axioms: IF (agent_is_dvija AND action_is_sarpa_hatya) THEN (restitution := [iron, kārṣṇāyasi, palāla, sesame_seed(1_masha)])
supreme_court_application: In matters involving ritual or ecological transgression, the Supreme Court shall assess the agent's dvija status and determine appropriate restorative restitution based on energetic disturbance caused. The focus remains on completion rather than condemnation.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that killing disrupts natural harmony; anupūrvaśaḥ demands sequential correction; proportional responsibility mandates symbolic-material return; non-punitive reality ensures no suffering accrues to the agent beyond the need for completion.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate offering protocol: distribute specified materials at sacred site
Engage mantra-shuddhi process until vibrational alignment resumes
Assign daily sankalpa practice until consciousness stabilizes
Verify integration through bi-weekly dharmic audit cycles
final_declaration: This ruling flows directly from the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam. Dharma stands restored. No punishment inheres. Consciousness alone adjudicates.
